description: The Denver Broncos' logo and lettering was spotted at both end zones at the Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, California, leaving out their opposition the Carolina Panthers.
title: Super Bowl grounds crew accidentally paint BOTH end zones for the Broncos
title_page: Super Bowl grounds crew accidentally paint BOTH end zones for the Broncos | Daily Mail Online
text:
Blundering Super Bowl officials accidentally painted both end zones for the Denver Broncos, completely forgetting about the Carolina Panthers.
Pictures taken at the Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, California, showed one end zone painted dark blue, with orange letters spelling out the word 'Broncos' emblazoned across it.
But, curiously, the other end zone remained unpainted - or so it seemed.
On closer inspection, the faint remains of the Broncos logo and lettering can be seen at the Panthers' end.
See the faint remains of 'BRONCOS' in the end zone? Grounds crew painted the logo on the wrong side. #SuperBowl50 pic.twitter.com/Jzy060MCzO â€” James Martin (@Jamesco) January 26, 2016
Samuel Lam spotted the Broncos' logo at both ends of the field. The one that will stay us below, while a faint one is seen at the top of the picture
The photographs, taken earlier this week by sports reporters visiting the ground, revealed that ground crews had painted both ends for the Broncos.
But the Panthers - who bookmakers have as favorites to win the big game on February 7 - need not be upset, as the error has already been corrected.
Their end zone, which is black with blue lettering, was finished on Thursday, CBS Sports reported.
The grounds crew have also finished painting the Super Bowl 50 logo in both halves of the field, as well as the NFL insignia in the center.
Some pointed out similarities between the blunder and a Snickers Super Bowl advert in 1996.
The commercial showed a hungry groundsman painting one of the end zones wrongly, accidentally spelling out the Kansas City 'Chefs' in their end zone.
Before and after: Above, a faint logo of the Denver Broncos can be seen in the bottom right of the nearest end zone. Below, the Carolina Panthers' end zone is now ready for the big game
The grounds crew have also finished painting the Super Bowl 50 logo in both halves of the field, as well as the NFL insignia (pictured) in the center
More than 115million people in the United States are expected to tune in for next Sunday's game, with quarterbacks Cam Newton and Peyton Manning set to face off for the Vince Lombardi Trophy.
An estimated 70,000 people will be in the stadium for the big game, paying more than $5,000 for a ticket on average.
Coldplay will be this year's half time show entertainment, with the help of Beyonce and Bruno Mars.
